conclusion: Solve step-by-step to find voltage across MN and direction of induced current through fixed resistor.
Two parallel guide-rails ab and cd separated by distance l.
Fixed resistor R connects points b and d.
Conductor rod MN (with resistance R) lies perpendicular to the rails.
Uniform magnetic field B perpendicular to the plane (into the paper).
Rod MN moves at constant velocity v along the rails.
EMF induced in moving rod is given by \( \mathcal{E} = Blv \).
B is magnetic field intensity, l is length of conductor, v is velocity of conductor.
Induced EMF is across the rod MN.
Using Fleming's right-hand rule, induced EMF creates electric field from N to M.
Potential at M is higher than at N.
Circuit consists of rod MN (resistance R), fixed resistor between b and d (resistance R), and rails (negligible resistance).
Induced EMF in rod MN acts as a voltage source.
Voltage across MN is \( U = Blv \).
Current flows from M to N within rod, M to b along top rail, b to d through fixed resistor, d to N along bottom rail.
Current through fixed resistor flows from b to d.
Magnitude of voltage U across MN is \( U = Blv \).
Induced current through fixed resistor R flows from point b to point d.
